item.title: Coronavirus may never go away, World Health Organization warns
item.description: Experts say the disease may become embedded in populations in the same way that HIV has.

item.title: Coronavirus: Chancellor Rishi Sunak warns of 'significant recession'
item.description: The UK's economy shrank at the fastest pace since 2008 during the first three months of the year.

item.title: Coronavirus lockdown: Allowing family gatherings in England 'complicated'
item.description: England's deputy chief medical officer says allowing families to mix is an "important public health issue".

item.title: Coronavirus: PM quizzed over 'unexplained' care home deaths
item.description: Labour leader Sir Keir Starmer says 10,000 extra deaths in April must be accounted for, as he questions the PM.

item.title: Coronavirus: Up to 100 children affected by rare inflammatory reaction
item.description: The reaction is extremely rare and only affects a tiny number of children seriously.

item.title: 'Not safe to reopen schools,' warn teachers' unions
item.description: Department for Education's own scientist suggests virus might not spread less among children.

item.title: Chancellor Rishi Sunak mistakenly joins rebels in chlorine chicken vote
item.description: A Commons bid to guarantee post-Brexit food import standards is defeated - despite unexpected backing.

item.title: Buzzfeed to close UK news operation
item.description: The online media company says it will be focusing on stories for its US audiences.

item.title: Spurs star Alli held at knifepoint during robbery
item.description: Tottenham and England midfielder Dele Alli held at knifepoint after robbers break into his house in the early hours of Wednesday.

item.title: Afghan attack: Kabul clinic cares for babies after attack
item.description: A children's hospital in the Afghan capital takes in 19 babies who survived a horrific attack.

item.title: Ex-Trump aide Paul Manafort to serve sentence at home amid virus fears
item.description: Manafort, 71, spent about a year of a seven year sentence behind bars, but will serve the rest at home.

item.title: Coronavirus: German contact-tracing app takes different path to NHS
item.description: Germany's contact-tracing app will not accept self-diagnosis reports, despite NHS saying they can save lives.

item.title: Singing policeman Tim Jones's Rocky Horror video goes viral
item.description: Police officer Tim Jones's videos have been watched by more than four million people around the world.

item.title: Coronavirus: Images as England eases lockdown rules
item.description: Images from the day some of the lockdown rules are eased in England.

item.title: Coronavirus: How to wear a face covering?
item.description: Across the world, people are being asked to wear face coverings to help stop coronavirus from spreading.

item.title: Coronavirus: The funeral director storing hundreds of bodies in the crisis
item.description: Deaths caused by Covid-19 have led to a shortage of space in some mortuaries and delays to funerals.

item.title: Sausage dog missing in Middleton Tyas found using bacon
item.description: Seven-month-old Floyd spent three days on a 350-acre farm in Middleton Tyas before he returned.

item.title: Photographer seeks 'extraordinary' over-80s
item.description: Photographer Laura Page wins funding for a project she hopes will challenge ageism in the UK.

item.title: Nature crisis: Moths have 'secret role' as crucial pollinators
item.description: Fluttering creatures of the night are also vital pollinators of plants and flowers, say scientists.

item.title: Coronavirus: Family of 14 say life in lockdown is 'calmer'
item.description: Tom and Stacy Shaw say they are "coping well" while stuck at home with 12 of their children.

item.title: The faded beauty of abandoned cars across Europe and the US
item.description: Photographer Dieter Klein searched Europe and the US to discover cars lost to time.

item.title: Blue Peter: New presenter to be unveiled during lockdown
item.description: Mwaka Mudenda will join the Blue Peter team virtually - and be tasked with breaking a world record.

item.title: Coronavirus: What does a 'Covid-secure' office look like?
item.description: One way corridors and Perspex screens, the future of the office will look very different.

item.title: Abba’s Björn Ulvaeus fears for future of West End theatres
item.description: Abba’s Björn Ulvaeus, co-writer of musical Mamma Mia!, says he fears for the future of the West End.

item.title: Fighting for the pill in Japan
item.description: It took until 1999 for Japanese women to be allowed to take the contraceptive pill.

item.title: Coronavirus: Venezuelans struggling with fuel shortage
item.description: Venezuela has the world's largest reserves of oil, but Covid-19 has worsened the current crisis.

item.title: Lockdown update: All you need to know about new measures
item.description: With more restrictions eased in England on Wednesday, how will social and work life be different?

item.title: Coronavirus: 'We feel so lost' - Young face job despair
item.description: History shows school leavers' job prospects are often hardest hit after this kind of economic slump.

item.title: Coronavirus lockdown: Why garden centres reopened first
item.description: A national obsession and an industry at the mercy of the seasons meant it was time to (safely) open up.

item.title: Coronavirus and tipping: Will the outbreak make us more generous?
item.description: One service says tips are up 99%, and there's a powerful factor which affects how people give to others.

item.title: Why Admiral's 'flashy' England strip now commands respect
item.description: First worn 40 years ago, why was England's red, white and blue kit given a kicking by the pundits?

item.title: Leaf Arbuthnot: How rent-a-gran scheme sparked a debut novel
item.description: Leaf Arbuthnot's story of intergenerational friendship makes for a debut apt for the here and now.

item.title: India coronavirus: How police won hearts with cakes, songs and sacrifice
item.description: India's lockdown has brought the police and public closer, but will it last?

item.title: Saudi Arabia: Just how deep are its troubles?
item.description: It has been rocked by coronavirus, an oil price collapse and the fallout from a high-profile murder.

item.title: Coronavirus: 'I run lockdown marathons in the dead of night'
item.description: Runners tell of the dramatic ways their training has changed during the coronavirus lockdown.

item.title: Coronavirus: Are children at risk and do they spread it?
item.description: Children appear to be at low risk from the disease, but are they spreading it?

item.title: Face masks: How is Wales' advice different to England?
item.description: Wales is taking a different approach to the use of face masks than other UK nations.

item.title: Coronavirus: How lockdown rules differ in Northern Ireland
item.description: How Stormont's approach to easing restrictions differs from that taken by GB and the Republic of Ireland.

item.title: Playing tennis during coronavirus: What are the latest rules on safety?
item.description: One-to-one coaching, as well as a game of singles with someone from outside your household, will be permitted in England from Wednesday.

item.title: Coronavirus doctor's diary: 'They say I have blood on my hands'
item.description: Abusive messages were sent to an Asian doctor because of a myth that non-white patients are left to die.

item.title: Lockdown: ‘Noisy neighbours are ruining my life’
item.description: Several UK councils report a rise in noise complaints since the start of the lockdown.

item.title: Coronavirus: 'I could be forced to lose a job I love'
item.description: Short notice from the government about returning to work has caused problems for some.

item.title: The robot assistant that can guess what you want
item.description: In a five-year project a group of robotics experts have developed a robot that can assist in maintenance tasks.

item.title: Coronavirus: Seacole hospital 'a tribute' to BAME NHS staff
item.description: A new community hospital recognises Jamaican-born nurse Mary Seacole - and BAME staff who have died.

item.title: Joshna Maharaj - The chef who lost her sense of smell
item.description: Chef Joshna Maharaj couldn't smell for years. Now she's working to regain some of what she lost.

item.title: The tech industry's winners and losers in lockdown
item.description: Unprecedented times are bad news for many - but not all. Some major technology companies are thriving.

item.title: Coronavirus: What should my employer do to keep me safe?
item.description: The government has published new guidance on how workplaces should be made safe amid the pandemic.

item.title: Sainz set to replace Vettel at Ferrari & Ricciardo poised to join McLaren
item.description: Carlos Sainz is poised to replace Sebastian Vettel at Ferrari with Daniel Ricciardo set to take the Spaniard's seat at McLaren.

item.title: Mike Tyson: Eddie Hearn says potential return poses moral dilemma for promoters
item.description: Promoter Eddie Hearn says someone has "reached out" to him about Mike Tyson's rumoured return to boxing.

item.title: West Indies players 'very nervous' about touring England
item.description: Cricket West Indies chief executive Johnny Grave thinks the tour of England will go ahead, but says his players will be "very nervous" about travelling.

item.title: Elite athletes given government guidance on safe return to training during coronavirus
item.description: Elite athletes will now be able to return to group training, provided social distancing is maintained and safety measures met.

item.title: No 'catastrophe' if Bundesliga player tests positive, say Dortmund
item.description: A player testing positive for coronavirus will not be a 'catastrophe' for the Bundesliga, Borussia Dortmund's managing director says.

item.title: Non-US golfers will have to quarantine before PGA Tour resumes
item.description: Leading professional golfers based outside the United States must quarantine in America before resuming the PGA Tour season next month.

item.title: Aluko apologises for tweets about people on furlough
item.description: Ex-England forward Eniola Aluko apologises after posting a series of tweets appearing to criticise people placed on furlough.

item.title: Coronavirus lockdown: Am I allowed to move house?
item.description: The easing of lockdown will affect those who want to buy or sell a home, or rent somewhere new, in England.

item.title: Can university students get a fee refund?
item.description: Can university students get a fee refund? and other questions answered by BBC experts.

item.title: Coronavirus: What are social distancing and self-isolation rules?
item.description: Boris Johnson has announced changes to guidelines in England on exercise and social distancing.

item.title: Coronavirus: What's the risk on public transport?
item.description: Bus and train operators are reducing services and increasing cleaning.

item.title: What should I do to stop the virus spreading?
item.description: Step-by-step, what to do to help prevent the spread of the virus.

item.title: Coronavirus: Does lockdown easing 'follow the science'?
item.description: Why is England pressing ahead with plans to ease lockdown rules ahead of the rest of the UK?

item.title: Coronavirus UK map: How many confirmed cases are there in your area?
item.description: Key graphics explaining how coronavirus has spread in the UK and the government's response.

item.title: Coronavirus: What does it mean if I've been furloughed by work?
item.description: Millions unable to do their job due to coronavirus will have their wages paid by a new scheme.

item.title: How do I travel to work now?
item.description: Some people are being encouraged to go back to work, but how will they get there?

item.title: How to make your own face mask
item.description: Our guide to different types of face coverings and step-by-step instructions on how to make them.

item.title: Coronavirus: Do I have to go back to work after lockdown?
item.description: With lockdown restrictions eased, people may start going back to work. But what are your rights?

item.title: Coronavirus: Who should wear a face mask or face covering?
item.description: For the first time, people in England are being advised to wear face coverings in some situations.

item.title: Coronavirus: When will schools reopen?
item.description: Schools have been closed to most pupils since the end of March - when and how will they open?

item.title: Coronavirus R0: What is the R number and why does it matter?
item.description: Experts keep discussing the value of R, but what is it and why does it matter?

item.title: Coronavirus: What is the UK's test, track and trace strategy?
item.description: A guide to the three key parts of the government's coronavirus strategy after lockdowns are eased.

item.title: Coronavirus: What are the new travel quarantine rules?
item.description: What do you need to know if you're planning to fly during the Covid-19 pandemic?

item.title: Coronavirus: Intensive care and other key terms explained
item.description: Use our tool to check the meaning of key words and phrases associated with the Covid-19 outbreak.

item.title: Coronavirus: How lockdown is being lifted across Europe
item.description: As the UK alters its restrictions, how do other European countries plan to re-open after lockdown?

item.title: Coronavirus: Labour's Starmer says PM statement 'raises as many questions as answers'
item.description: People are being told to go back to work without clear safety guidance, Labour leader Keir Starmer says.

item.title: 'I stole a plane to get out of the Navy'
item.description: When Theo Van Eijck was kicked out of a Dutch pilot-training programme in 1964, he stole a plane and flew to Libya.
